conclusion: Determine how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves to the back right.
The current shadows suggest the light source is coming from the front left.
The light source moves to the back right, meaning the light will now come from a direction opposite to the current one.
Shadows will form in the direction opposite to the light source, so they will shift towards the front left.
The angle of the light affects the length of the shadows; a lower light source creates longer shadows.
Assuming the light height remains constant, the shadows will elongate as they shift.
Object A (Cake): The shadow will move towards the front left and may become longer.
Object B (Nail): The shadow will also shift to the front left and could elongate.
Object C (First Aid Kit): The shadow will move to the front left and may stretch out.
Object D (Ring): The shadow will shift to the front left and could become more elongated.
Depending on the objects' positions, shadows might overlap more or less as they shift.
Final Answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shift towards the front left and likely become longer due to the change in the light's angle.
